The interconnections or changes—including upgrading or replacing applications, operating systems, and firmware—may adversely affect previously implemented controls. Ongoing assessment during development allows for additional types of testing and evaluation that developers can conduct to reduce or eliminate potential flaws. Testing custom software applications may require approaches such as manual code review, security architecture review, and penetration testing, as well as static analysis, dynamic analysis, binary analysis, or a hybrid of the three analysis approaches. Developers can use the analysis approaches, along with security instrumentation and fuzzing, in a variety of tools and in source code reviews. The security and privacy assessment plans include the specific activities that developers plan to carry out, including the types of analyses, testing, evaluation, and reviews of software and firmware components; the degree of rigor to be applied; the frequency of the ongoing testing and evaluation; and the types of artifacts produced during those processes. The depth of testing and evaluation refers to the rigor and level of detail associated with the assessment process. The coverage of testing and evaluation refers to the scope (i.e., number and type) of the artifacts included in the assessment process. Contracts specify the acceptance criteria for security and privacy assessment plans, flaw remediation processes, and the evidence that the plans and processes have been diligently applied. Methods for reviewing and protecting assessment plans, evidence, and documentation are commensurate with the security category or classification level of the system. Contracts may specify protection requirements for documentation.

subsection_controls.Name: SA-11(8) - Developer Testing and Evaluation

control.description: Require the developer of the system, system component, or system service to employ dynamic code analysis tools to identify common flaws and document the results of the analysis.
requirements: Require the developer of the system, system component, or system service to employ dynamic code analysis tools to identify common flaws and document the results of the analysis.
control.title: Dynamic Code Analysis
control.discussion: Dynamic code analysis provides runtime verification of software programs using tools capable of monitoring programs for memory corruption, user privilege issues, and other potential security problems. Dynamic code analysis employs runtime tools to ensure that security functionality performs in the way it was designed. A type of dynamic analysis, known as fuzz testing, induces program failures by deliberately introducing malformed or random data into software programs. Fuzz testing strategies are derived from the intended use of applications and the functional and design specifications for the applications. To understand the scope of dynamic code analysis and the assurance provided, organizations may also consider conducting code coverage analysis (i.e., checking the degree to which the code has been tested using metrics such as percent of subroutines tested or percent of program statements called during execution of the test suite) and/or concordance analysis (i.e., checking for words that are out of place in software code, such as non-English language words or derogatory terms).

subsection_controls.discussion: Developmental testing and evaluation confirms that the required controls are implemented correctly, operating as intended, enforcing the desired security and privacy policies, and meeting established security and privacy requirements. Security properties of systems and the privacy of individuals may be affected by the interconnection of system components or changes to those components. The interconnections or changes—including upgrading or replacing applications, operating systems, and firmware—may adversely affect previously implemented controls. Ongoing assessment during development allows for additional types of testing and evaluation that developers can conduct to reduce or eliminate potential flaws. Testing custom software applications may require approaches such as manual code review, security architecture review, and penetration testing, as well as static analysis, dynamic analysis, binary analysis, or a hybrid of the three analysis approaches. Developers can use the analysis approaches, along with security instrumentation and fuzzing, in a variety of tools and in source code reviews. The security and privacy assessment plans include the specific activities that developers plan to carry out, including the types of analyses, testing, evaluation, and reviews of software and firmware components; the degree of rigor to be applied; the frequency of the ongoing testing and evaluation; and the types of artifacts produced during those processes. The depth of testing and evaluation refers to the rigor and level of detail associated with the assessment process. The coverage of testing and evaluation refers to the scope (i.e., number and type) of the artifacts included in the assessment process. Contracts specify the acceptance criteria for security and privacy assessment plans, flaw remediation processes, and the evidence that the plans and processes have been diligently applied. Methods for reviewing and protecting assessment plans, evidence, and documentation are commensurate with the security category or classification level of the system. Contracts may specify protection requirements for documentation.

subsection_controls.Name: SA-11(9) - Developer Testing and Evaluation

control.description: Require the developer of the system, system component, or system service to employ interactive application security testing tools to identify flaws and document the results.
requirements: Require the developer of the system, system component, or system service to employ interactive application security testing tools to identify flaws and document the results.
control.title: Interactive Application Security Testing
control.discussion: Interactive (also known as instrumentation-based) application security testing is a method of detecting vulnerabilities by observing applications as they run during testing. The use of instrumentation relies on direct measurements of the actual running applications and uses access to the code, user interaction, libraries, frameworks, backend connections, and configurations to directly measure control effectiveness. When combined with analysis techniques, interactive application security testing can identify a broad range of potential vulnerabilities and confirm control effectiveness. Instrumentation-based testing works in real time and can be used continuously throughout the system development life cycle.

subsection_controls.discussion: Developmental testing and evaluation confirms that the required controls are implemented correctly, operating as intended, enforcing the desired security and privacy policies, and meeting established security and privacy requirements. Security properties of systems and the privacy of individuals may be affected by the interconnection of system components or changes to those components. The interconnections or changes—including upgrading or replacing applications, operating systems, and firmware—may adversely affect previously implemented controls. Ongoing assessment during development allows for additional types of testing and evaluation that developers can conduct to reduce or eliminate potential flaws. Testing custom software applications may require approaches such as manual code review, security architecture review, and penetration testing, as well as static analysis, dynamic analysis, binary analysis, or a hybrid of the three analysis approaches. Developers can use the analysis approaches, along with security instrumentation and fuzzing, in a variety of tools and in source code reviews. The security and privacy assessment plans include the specific activities that developers plan to carry out, including the types of analyses, testing, evaluation, and reviews of software and firmware components; the degree of rigor to be applied; the frequency of the ongoing testing and evaluation; and the types of artifacts produced during those processes. The depth of testing and evaluation refers to the rigor and level of detail associated with the assessment process. The coverage of testing and evaluation refers to the scope (i.e., number and type) of the artifacts included in the assessment process. Contracts specify the acceptance criteria for security and privacy assessment plans, flaw remediation processes, and the evidence that the plans and processes have been diligently applied. Methods for reviewing and protecting assessment plans, evidence, and documentation are commensurate with the security category or classification level of the system. Contracts may specify protection requirements for documentation.

subsection_controls.Name: SA-15-description - Development Process, Standards, and Tools

control.description: Require the developer of the system, system component, or system service to follow a documented development process addressing security and privacy requirements, standards, tools, and integrity of changes.
requirements: Require the developer of the system, system component, or system service to follow a documented development process addressing security and privacy requirements, standards, tools, and integrity of changes.

subsection_controls.discussion: Development tools include programming languages and computer-aided design systems. Reviews of development processes include the use of maturity models to determine the potential effectiveness of such processes. Maintaining the integrity of changes to tools and processes facilitates effective supply chain risk assessment and mitigation.

subsection_controls.Name: SA-15(1) - Development Process, Standards, and Tools

control.description: Define quality metrics at the beginning of development and provide evidence of meeting them at specified frequency or milestones.
requirements: Define quality metrics at the beginning of development and provide evidence of meeting them at specified frequency or milestones.
control.title: Quality Metrics
control.discussion: Organizations use quality metrics to establish acceptable levels of system quality. Metrics can include quality gates, severity thresholds of vulnerabilities, and ensure no known vulnerabilities in the delivered system with medium or high CVSS severity.

subsection_controls.discussion: Development tools include programming languages and computer-aided design systems. Reviews of development processes include the use of maturity models to determine the potential effectiveness of such processes. Maintaining the integrity of changes to tools and processes facilitates effective supply chain risk assessment and mitigation.

requirements: Select and employ security and privacy tracking tools during the development process.

subsection_controls.discussion: Development tools include programming languages and computer-aided design systems. requirements: Minimize the use of personally identifiable information in development and test environments.

subsection_controls.Name: SA-16-description - Developer-Provided Training

control.description: Require the developer of the system, system component, or system service to provide organization-defined training on the correct use and operation of implemented security and privacy functions, controls, and mechanisms.
requirements: Require the developer of the system, system component, or system service to provide organization-defined training on the correct use and operation of implemented security and privacy functions, controls, and mechanisms.

subsection_controls.discussion: Developer-provided training applies to external and internal developers. Training personnel is essential to ensuring the effectiveness of controls. Types of training include web-based, computer-based, classroom-style, and hands-on (including micro-training). Organizations may request training materials from developers or offer self-training. Organizations determine the type of training necessary and may require different types for different security and privacy functions, controls, and mechanisms.

subsection_controls.Name: SA-17-description - Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design
subsection_controls.control_title: Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design

control.description: Require the developer to produce a design specification and security and privacy architecture consistent with the organization’s security and privacy enterprise architecture, accurately describing functionality, allocation of controls, and interactions between functions and mechanisms.
requirements: Require the developer to produce a design specification and security and privacy architecture consistent with the organization’s security and privacy enterprise architecture, accurately describing functionality, allocation of controls, and interactions between functions and mechanisms.

subsection_controls.discussion: Directed at external developers, but applicable to internal development. Ensures consistency with enterprise architecture. ISO 15408-2, ISO 15408-3, and SP 800-160-1 provide guidance on security architecture and design.

subsection_controls.Name: SA-17(1) - Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design
subsection_controls.control_title: Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design

control.description: Produce a formal policy model as part of development, proving it is internally consistent and sufficient to enforce defined organizational security and privacy policy elements.
requirements: Produce a formal policy model as part of development, proving it is internally consistent and sufficient to enforce defined organizational security and privacy policy elements.
control.title: Formal Policy Model
control.discussion: Formal models describe specific behaviors or policies using formal languages, enabling correctness proofs for those policies. Not all components can be modeled; scoping is based on behaviors of interest.

subsection_controls.discussion: Directed at external developers, but applicable to internal development. Ensures consistency with enterprise architecture. ISO 15408-2, ISO 15408-3, and SP 800-160-1 provide guidance on security architecture and design.

subsection_controls.Name: SA-17(2) - Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design
subsection_controls.control_title: Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design

control.description: Define security-relevant hardware, software, and firmware and provide rationale that the definition is complete.
requirements: Define security-relevant hardware, software, and firmware and provide rationale that the definition is complete.
control.title: Security-Relevant Components
control.discussion: Represents portions of the system trusted to maintain required security properties.

subsection_controls.discussion: Directed at external developers, but applicable to internal development. Ensures consistency with enterprise architecture. ISO 15408-2, ISO 15408-3, and SP 800-160-1 provide guidance on security architecture and design.

subsection_controls.Name: SA-17(3) - Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design
subsection_controls.control_title: Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design

control.description: Produce a formal top-level specification of interfaces to security-relevant components and demonstrate consistency with formal policy model and accuracy of implementation.
requirements: Produce a formal top-level specification of interfaces to security-relevant components and demonstrate consistency with formal policy model and accuracy of implementation.
control.title: Formal Correspondence
control.discussion: Ensures implementation is accurate transformation of the model; formal and informal methods may be used to demonstrate consistency. Includes mapping of internal mechanisms.

subsection_controls.discussion: Directed at external developers, but applicable to internal development. Ensures consistency with enterprise architecture. ISO 15408-2, ISO 15408-3, and SP 800-160-1 provide guidance on security architecture and design.

subsection_controls.Name: SA-17(4) - Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design
subsection_controls.control_title: Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design

control.description: Produce an informal descriptive top-level specification of interfaces to security-relevant components, demonstrating consistency with the formal policy model and accuracy of implementation.
requirements: Produce an informal descriptive top-level specification of interfaces to security-relevant components, demonstrating consistency with the formal policy model and accuracy of implementation.
control.title: Informal Correspondence
control.discussion: Shows implementation accurately reflects model; combination of formal and informal methods may be needed. Includes internal mechanisms.

subsection_controls.discussion: Directed at external developers, but applicable to internal development. Ensures consistency with enterprise architecture. ISO 15408-2, ISO 15408-3, and SP 800-160-1 provide guidance on security architecture and design.

subsection_controls.Name: SA-17(5) - Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design
subsection_controls.control_title: Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design

control.description: Design and structure security-relevant components using complete, conceptually simple protection mechanisms with clearly defined semantics, and internally structure components accordingly.
requirements: Design and structure security-relevant components using complete, conceptually simple protection mechanisms with clearly defined semantics, and internally structure components accordingly.
control.title: Conceptually Simple Design
control.discussion: Reduced complexity improves understandability, correctness, completeness, and reduces vulnerabilities. Simpler systems have higher assurance of security functions.

subsection_controls.discussion: Directed at external developers, but applicable to internal development. Ensures consistency with enterprise architecture. ISO 15408-2, ISO 15408-3, and SP 800-160-1 provide guidance on security architecture and design.

subsection_controls.Name: SA-17(6) - Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design
subsection_controls.control_title: Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design

control.description: Structure security-relevant components to facilitate testing.
requirements: Structure security-relevant components to facilitate testing.
control.title: Structure for Testing
control.discussion: Supports comprehensive testing and evidence generation for system trustworthiness.

subsection_controls.discussion: Directed at external developers, but applicable to internal development. Ensures consistency with enterprise architecture. ISO 15408-2, ISO 15408-3, and SP 800-160-1 provide guidance on security architecture and design.

subsection_controls.Name: SA-17(7) - Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design
subsection_controls.control_title: Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design

control.description: Structure components to control access with least privilege.
requirements: Structure components to control access with least privilege.
control.title: Structure for Least Privilege
control.discussion: Applies least privilege internally and externally to minimize impact of failures or misuse and simplify security analysis.

subsection_controls.discussion: Directed at external developers, but applicable to internal development. Ensures consistency with enterprise architecture. ISO 15408-2, ISO 15408-3, and SP 800-160-1 provide guidance on security architecture and design.

subsection_controls.Name: SA-17(8) - Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design
subsection_controls.control_title: Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design

control.description: Design critical systems or components with coordinated behavior to implement organization-defined capabilities.
requirements: Design critical systems or components with coordinated behavior to implement organization-defined capabilities.
control.title: Orchestration
control.discussion: Coordination prevents negative interactions, cascading failures, or coverage gaps between distributed security resources.

subsection_controls.discussion: Directed at external developers, but applicable to internal development. Ensures consistency with enterprise architecture. ISO 15408-2, ISO 15408-3, and SP 800-160-1 provide guidance on security architecture and design.

subsection_controls.Name: SA-17(9) - Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design
subsection_controls.control_title: Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design

control.description: Use different designs for critical systems or components to satisfy common requirements or provide equivalent functionality.
requirements: Use different designs for critical systems or components to satisfy common requirements or provide equivalent functionality.
control.title: Design Diversity
control.discussion: Achieved by developing multiple variants; supports fault tolerance and reduces risk from uniform design vulnerabilities.

subsection_controls.discussion: Directed at external developers, but applicable to internal development. Ensures consistency with enterprise architecture. ISO 15408-2, ISO 15408-3, and SP 800-160-1 provide guidance on security architecture and design.

subsection_controls.Name: SA-20-description - Customized Development of Critical Components

control.description: Reimplement or custom develop the following critical system components: organization-defined critical system components.
requirements: Reimplement or custom develop the following critical system components: organization-defined critical system components.

subsection_controls.discussion: Organizations determine that certain system components cannot be trusted due to specific threats and vulnerabilities. Reimplementation or custom development increases assurance. If no alternative sourcing is available and reimplementation is not performed, additional controls include enhanced auditing, restrictions on source code and system utility access, and protection from deletion of system and application files.

subsection_controls.Name: SA-21-description - Developer Screening

control.description: Require that the developer of organization-defined system, system component, or system service: a) has appropriate access authorizations as determined by assigned official government duties; b) satisfies additional personnel screening criteria.
requirements: Require that the developer of organization-defined system, system component, or system service: a) has appropriate access authorizations as determined by assigned official government duties; b) satisfies additional personnel screening criteria.

subsection_controls.discussion: Developer screening ensures external developers are trustworthy. Authorization and screening criteria may include clearances, background checks, citizenship, nationality, and company ownership review. Organizations validate developer compliance with screening requirements.

subsection_controls.Name: SA-21(1) - Developer Screening

control.description: [Withdrawn: Incorporated into SA-21.]

control.title: Validation of Screening

subsection_controls.discussion: Developer screening ensures external developers are trustworthy. Authorization and screening criteria may include clearances, background checks, citizenship, nationality, and company ownership review. subsection_controls.Name: SA-22-description - Unsupported System Components

control.description: a. Replace system components when support for the components is no longer available from the developer, vendor, or manufacturer; or b. Provide the following options for alternative sources for continued support for unsupported components: in-house support; organization-defined support from external providers.
requirements: a. Replace system components when support for the components is no longer available from the developer, vendor, or manufacturer; or b. Provide the following options for alternative sources for continued support for unsupported components: in-house support; organization-defined support from external providers.

subsection_controls.discussion: Support for system components includes software patches, firmware updates, replacement parts, and maintenance contracts. Unsupported components include those for which vendors no longer provide critical software patches or product updates, creating opportunities for adversaries to exploit weaknesses. Exceptions exist for systems providing critical mission or business capabilities where newer technologies are unavailable or the system is isolated. Alternative support sources can include in-house support (customized patches) or external providers via contractual relationships. Increased risk can be mitigated by isolating unsupported components from public or uncontrolled networks.

subsection_controls.Name: SA-22(1) - Unsupported System Components

control.description: [Withdrawn: Incorporated into SA-22.]
requirements: [Withdrawn: Incorporated into SA-22.]
control.title: Alternative Sources for Continued Support

subsection_controls.discussion: Support for system components includes software patches, firmware updates, replacement parts, and maintenance contracts. Unsupported components include those for which vendors no longer provide critical software patches or product updates, creating opportunities for adversaries to exploit weaknesses. Exceptions exist for systems providing critical mission or business capabilities where newer technologies are unavailable or the system is isolated. Alternative support sources can include in-house support (customized patches) or external providers via contractual relationships. Increased risk can be mitigated by isolating unsupported components from public or uncontrolled networks.

subsection_controls.Name: SA-23-description - Specialization

control.description: Employ design, modification, augmentation, or reconfiguration on organization-defined systems or system components supporting mission-essential services or functions to increase the trustworthiness in those systems or components.
requirements: Employ design, modification, augmentation, or reconfiguration on organization-defined systems or system components supporting mission-essential services or functions to increase the trustworthiness in those systems or components.

subsection_controls.discussion: Systems or components that support mission-essential services may require enhancements to maximize trustworthiness. Enhancements may be done at the design level or post-design through modifications, augmentation, or reconfiguration. For example, supplemental authentication or non-repudiation functions may be added to enhance the identity of critical resources.

subsection_controls.Name: SC-1-description - Policy and Procedures

control.description: a. Develop, document, and disseminate to organization-defined personnel or roles: 1. Organization-level, Mission/business process-level, System-level system and communications protection policy that addresses purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, management commitment, coordination among organizational entities, and compliance; and is consistent with applicable laws, executive orders, directives, regulations, policies, standards, and guidelines; 2. Procedures to facilitate the implementation of the system and communications protection policy and associated system and communications protection controls; b. Designate an organization-defined official to manage the development, documentation, and dissemination of the system and communications protection policy and procedures; c. Review and update policy and procedures at organization-defined frequency and following organization-defined events.
requirements: a. Develop, document, and disseminate to organization-defined personnel or roles: 1. Organization-level, Mission/business process-level, System-level system and communications protection policy that addresses purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, management commitment, coordination among organizational entities, and compliance; and is consistent with applicable laws, executive orders, directives, regulations, policies, standards, and guidelines; 2. Procedures to facilitate the implementation of the system and communications protection policy and associated system and communications protection controls; b. Designate an organization-defined official to manage the development, documentation, and dissemination of the system and communications protection policy and procedures; c. Review and update policy and procedures at organization-defined frequency and following organization-defined events.

subsection_controls.discussion: System and communications protection policy and procedures address the controls in the SC family that are implemented within systems and organizations. Policies and procedures contribute to security and privacy assurance. Security and privacy program policies at the organization level are preferable, though mission- or system-specific policies may be established. Procedures describe how policies or controls are implemented and can be documented in system security and privacy plans. Events triggering updates include assessment findings, security incidents, or changes in applicable laws and policies. Simply restating controls does not constitute policy or procedures.

subsection_controls.Name: SC-2-description - Separation of System and User Functionality
subsection_controls.control_title: Separation of System and User Functionality

control.description: Separate user functionality, including user interface services, from system management functionality.
requirements: Separate user functionality, including user interface services, from system management functionality.

subsection_controls.discussion: System management functions, which require privileged access, should be separated from user functions physically or logically. Methods include different computers, OS instances, CPUs, network addresses, virtualization, or combinations thereof. This includes web administrative interfaces and can be guided by systems security engineering principles in SA-8, including SA-8(1), SA-8(3), SA-8(4), SA-8(10), SA-8(12), SA-8(13), SA-8(14), and SA-8(18).

subsection_controls.Name: SC-2(1) - Separation of System and User Functionality
subsection_controls.control_title: Separation of System and User Functionality

control.description: Prevent the presentation of system management functionality at interfaces to non-privileged users.
requirements: Prevent the presentation of system management functionality at interfaces to non-privileged users.
control.title: Interfaces for Non-Privileged Users
control.discussion: Ensures system administration options are not available to general users. Can withhold options until sessions with administrator privileges are established.

subsection_controls.discussion: System management functions, which require privileged access, should be separated from user functions physically or logically. Methods include different computers, OS instances, CPUs, network addresses, virtualization, or combinations thereof. This includes web administrative interfaces and can be guided by systems security engineering principles in SA-8, including SA-8(1), SA-8(3), SA-8(4), SA-8(10), SA-8(12), SA-8(13), SA-8(14), and SA-8(18).

subsection_controls.Name: SC-2(2) - Separation of System and User Functionality
subsection_controls.control_title: Separation of System and User Functionality

control.description: Store state information from applications and software separately.
requirements: Store state information from applications and software separately.
control.title: Disassociability
control.discussion: Separating applications and software from user interaction state can better protect privacy if the system is compromised.

subsection_controls.discussion: System management functions, which require privileged access, should be separated from user functions physically or logically. Methods include different computers, OS instances, CPUs, network addresses, virtualization, or combinations thereof. This includes web administrative interfaces and can be guided by systems security engineering principles in SA-8, including SA-8(1), SA-8(3), SA-8(4), SA-8(10), SA-8(12), SA-8(13), SA-8(14), and SA-8(18).

subsection_controls.Name: SC-3-description - Security Function Isolation

control.description: Isolate security functions from nonsecurity functions.
requirements: Isolate security functions from nonsecurity functions.

subsection_controls.discussion: Security functions are isolated using partitions and domains to protect integrity. Isolation may involve processor rings, memory protections, access control, and least privilege enforcement. Nonsecurity functions may be included minimally where strict isolation is not feasible. Systems security engineering principles in SA-8, including SA-8(1), SA-8(3), SA-8(4), SA-8(10), SA-8(12), SA-8(13), SA-8(14), and SA-8(18), can be applied.

subsection_controls.Name: SC-3(1) - Security Function Isolation

control.description: Employ hardware separation mechanisms to implement security function isolation.
requirements: Employ hardware separation mechanisms to implement security function isolation.
control.title: Hardware Separation
control.discussion: Hardware separation includes ring architectures in microprocessors and hardware-enforced address segmentation to support logically distinct storage objects.

subsection_controls.discussion: Security functions are isolated using partitions and domains to protect integrity. Isolation may involve processor rings, memory protections, access control, and least privilege enforcement. Nonsecurity functions may be included minimally where strict isolation is not feasible. Systems security engineering principles in SA-8, including SA-8(1), SA-8(3), SA-8(4), SA-8(10), SA-8(12), SA-8(13), SA-8(14), and SA-8(18), can be applied.

subsection_controls.Name: SC-3(2) - Security Function Isolation

control.description: Isolate security functions enforcing access and information flow control from nonsecurity functions and other security functions.
requirements: Isolate security functions enforcing access and information flow control from nonsecurity functions and other security functions.
control.title: Access and Flow Control Functions
control.discussion: Functions such as auditing, intrusion detection, and malicious code protection may be isolated from access and flow control enforcement.

subsection_controls.discussion: Security functions are isolated using partitions and domains to protect integrity. Isolation may involve processor rings, memory protections, access control, and least privilege enforcement. Nonsecurity functions may be included minimally where strict isolation is not feasible. Systems security engineering principles in SA-8, including SA-8(1), SA-8(3), SA-8(4), SA-8(10), SA-8(12), SA-8(13), SA-8(14), and SA-8(18), can be applied.

subsection_controls.Name: SC-3(3) - Security Function Isolation

control.description: Minimize nonsecurity functions within the isolation boundary containing security functions.
requirements: Minimize nonsecurity functions within the isolation boundary containing security functions.
control.title: Minimize Nonsecurity Functionality
control.discussion: Reduces trusted code complexity and enhances understandability. Nonsecurity functions may impact security-relevant functions if errors or malicious code exist.

subsection_controls.discussion: Security functions are isolated using partitions and domains to protect integrity. Isolation may involve processor rings, memory protections, access control, and least privilege enforcement. Nonsecurity functions may be included minimally where strict isolation is not feasible. Systems security engineering principles in SA-8, including SA-8(1), SA-8(3), SA-8(4), SA-8(10), SA-8(12), SA-8(13), SA-8(14), and SA-8(18), can be applied.

subsection_controls.Name: SC-3(4) - Security Function Isolation

control.description: Implement security functions as independent modules with high cohesion and minimal coupling.
requirements: Implement security functions as independent modules with high cohesion and minimal coupling.
control.title: Module Coupling and Cohesiveness
control.discussion: Reduces inter-module interactions, constraining security functions and managing complexity.

subsection_controls.discussion: Security functions are isolated using partitions and domains to protect integrity. Isolation may involve processor rings, memory protections, access control, and least privilege enforcement. Nonsecurity functions may be included minimally where strict isolation is not feasible. Systems security engineering principles in SA-8, including SA-8(1), SA-8(3), SA-8(4), SA-8(10), SA-8(12), SA-8(13), SA-8(14), and SA-8(18), can be applied.

subsection_controls.Name: SC-3(5) - Security Function Isolation

control.description: Implement security functions as a layered structure minimizing interactions between layers and avoiding lower layers depending on higher layers.
requirements: Implement security functions as a layered structure minimizing interactions between layers and avoiding lower layers depending on higher layers.
control.title: Layered Structures
control.discussion: Enables isolation and manages complexity within the system design.

subsection_controls.discussion: Security functions are isolated using partitions and domains to protect integrity. Isolation may involve processor rings, memory protections, access control, and least privilege enforcement. Nonsecurity functions may be included minimally where strict isolation is not feasible. Systems security engineering principles in SA-8, including SA-8(1), SA-8(3), SA-8(4), SA-8(10), SA-8(12), SA-8(13), SA-8(14), and SA-8(18), can be applied.

subsection_controls.Name: SC-4-description - Information in Shared System Resources

control.description: Prevent unauthorized and unintended information transfer via shared system resources.
requirements: Prevent unauthorized and unintended information transfer via shared system resources.

subsection_controls.discussion: Preventing unauthorized and unintended information transfer via shared system resources stops information produced by prior users or roles from being available to current users or roles after resources have been released. Applies to encrypted representations of information. Does not address information remanence or covert channels. Not applicable to single-user components.

subsection_controls.Name: SC-4(1) - Information in Shared System Resources

control.description: [Withdrawn: Incorporated into SC-4]
requirements: [Withdrawn: Incorporated into SC-4]
control.title: Security Levels

subsection_controls.discussion: Preventing unauthorized and unintended information transfer via shared system resources stops information produced by prior users or roles from being available to current users or roles after resources have been released. Applies to encrypted representations of information. Does not address information remanence or covert channels. Not applicable to single-user components.

subsection_controls.Name: SC-4(2) - Information in Shared System Resources

control.description: Prevent unauthorized information transfer via shared resources according to organization-defined procedures when system processing switches between different information classification levels or security categories.
requirements: Prevent unauthorized information transfer via shared resources according to organization-defined procedures when system processing switches between different information classification levels or security categories.
control.title: Multilevel or Periods Processing
control.discussion: Changes in processing levels can occur during multilevel or periods processing. Procedures may include approved sanitization processes for electronically stored information.

subsection_controls.discussion: Preventing unauthorized and unintended information transfer via shared system resources stops information produced by prior users or roles from being available to current users or roles after resources have been released. Applies to encrypted representations of information. Does not address information remanence or covert channels. Not applicable to single-user components.

subsection_controls.Name: SC-5-description - Denial-of-Service Protection

control.description: a. Protect against or limit the effects of organization-defined types of denial-of-service events; b. Employ organization-defined controls to achieve denial-of-service objectives.
requirements: a. Protect against or limit the effects of organization-defined types of denial-of-service events; b. Employ organization-defined controls to achieve denial-of-service objectives.

subsection_controls.discussion: Denial-of-service events may occur due to internal or external causes, such as attacks or insufficient capacity. Technologies to limit or prevent these attacks include boundary protection devices, increased bandwidth, and service redundancy.

subsection_controls.Name: SC-5(1) - Denial-of-Service Protection

control.description: Restrict individuals from launching denial-of-service attacks against other systems.
requirements: Restrict individuals from launching denial-of-service attacks against other systems.
control.title: Restrict Ability to Attack Other Systems
control.discussion: Prevents hostile insiders or external adversaries from launching attacks. May involve restricting connection/transmission on transport media and limiting system resource usage.

subsection_controls.discussion: Denial-of-service events may occur due to internal or external causes, such as attacks or insufficient capacity. Technologies to limit or prevent these attacks include boundary protection devices, increased bandwidth, and service redundancy.

subsection_controls.Name: SC-5(2) - Denial-of-Service Protection

control.description: Manage capacity, bandwidth, or other redundancy to limit effects of information flooding denial-of-service attacks.
requirements: Manage capacity, bandwidth, or other redundancy to limit effects of information flooding denial-of-service attacks.
control.title: Capacity, Bandwidth, and Redundancy
control.discussion: Ensures sufficient capacity to counter flooding attacks. Methods include usage priorities, quotas, partitioning, and load balancing.

subsection_controls.discussion: Denial-of-service events may occur due to internal or external causes, such as attacks or insufficient capacity. Technologies to limit or prevent these attacks include boundary protection devices, increased bandwidth, and service redundancy.

subsection_controls.Name: SC-5(3) - Denial-of-Service Protection

control.description: a. Employ monitoring tools to detect indicators of denial-of-service attacks; b. Monitor system resources to ensure sufficient capacity to prevent effective attacks.
requirements: a. Employ monitoring tools to detect indicators of denial-of-service attacks; b. Monitor system resources to ensure sufficient capacity to prevent effective attacks.
control.title: Detection and Monitoring
control.discussion: Considers utilization and capacity of sensitive resources (disk, memory, CPU). Techniques include quotas, alerts, compression, and partitioning for system/user data.

subsection_controls.discussion: Denial-of-service events may occur due to internal or external causes, such as attacks or insufficient capacity. Technologies to limit or prevent these attacks include boundary protection devices, increased bandwidth, and service redundancy.

subsection_controls.Name: SC-6-description - RESOURCE AVAILABILITY

control.description: Protect the availability of resources by allocating [Assignment: organization-defined resources] by [Selection (one or more): priority; quota; [Assignment: organization-defined controls]].
requirements: Protect the availability of resources by allocating [Assignment: organization-defined resources] by [Selection (one or more): priority; quota; [Assignment: organization-defined controls]].

subsection_controls.discussion: Priority protection prevents lower-priority processes from delaying or interfering with the system that services higher-priority processes. Quotas prevent users or processes from obtaining more than predetermined amounts of resources.

subsection_controls.Name: SC-7-description - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.description: a. Monitor and control communications at the external managed interfaces to the system and at key internal managed interfaces within the system; b. Implement subnetworks for publicly accessible system components that are [Selection: physically; logically] separated from internal organizational networks; and c. Connect to external networks or systems only through managed interfaces consisting of boundary protection devices arranged in accordance with an organizational security and privacy architecture.
requirements: a. Monitor and control communications at the external managed interfaces to the system and at key internal managed interfaces within the system; b. Implement subnetworks for publicly accessible system components that are [Selection: physically; logically] separated from internal organizational networks; and c. Connect to external networks or systems only through managed interfaces consisting of boundary protection devices arranged in accordance with an organizational security and privacy architecture.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. Subnetworks that are physically or logically separated from internal networks are referred to as demilitarized zones or DMZs. Restricting or prohibiting interfaces within organizational systems includes restricting external web traffic to designated web servers within managed interfaces, prohibiting external traffic that appears to be spoofing internal addresses, and prohibiting internal traffic that appears to be spoofing external addresses. [SP 800-189] provides additional information on source address validation techniques to prevent ingress and egress of traffic with spoofed addresses. Commercial telecommunications services are provided by network components and consolidated management systems shared by customers. These services may also include third party-provided access lines and other service elements. Such services may represent sources of increased risk despite contract security provisions. Boundary protection may be implemented as a common control for all or part of an organizational network such that the boundary to be protected is greater than a system-specific boundary (i.e., an authorization boundary).

subsection_controls.Name: (2) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION
subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. Boundary protection may be implemented as a common control for all or part of an organizational network such that the boundary to be protected is greater than a system-specific boundary (i.e., an authorization boundary).

subsection_controls.Name: (3) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: ACCESS POINTS
control.discussion: Limiting the number of external network connections facilitates monitoring of inbound and outbound communications traffic. The Trusted Internet Connection [DHS TIC] initiative is an example of a federal guideline that requires limits on the number of external network connections. Limiting the number of external network connections to the system is important during transition periods from older to newer technologies (e.g., transitioning from IPv4 to IPv6 network protocols). Such transitions may require implementing the older and newer technologies simultaneously during the transition period and thus increase the number of access points to the system.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. Subnetworks that are physically or logically separated from internal networks are referred to as demilitarized zones or DMZs. Restricting or prohibiting interfaces within organizational systems includes restricting external web traffic to designated web servers within managed interfaces, prohibiting external traffic that appears to be spoofing internal addresses, and prohibiting internal traffic that appears to be spoofing external addresses. [SP 800-189] provides additional information on source address validation techniques to prevent ingress and egress of traffic with spoofed addresses. Commercial telecommunications services are provided by network components and consolidated management systems shared by customers. These services may also include third party-provided access lines and other service elements. Such services may represent sources of increased risk despite contract security provisions. Boundary protection may be implemented as a common control for all or part of an organizational network such that the boundary to be protected is greater than a system-specific boundary (i.e., an authorization boundary).

subsection_controls.Name: (4) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: EXTERNAL TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICES
control.discussion: External telecommunications services can provide data and/or voice communications services. Examples of control plane traffic include Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) routing, Domain Name System (DNS), and management protocols. See [SP 800-189] for additional information on the use of the resource public key infrastructure (RPKI) to protect BGP routes and detect unauthorized BGP announcements.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. Subnetworks that are physically or logically separated from internal networks are referred to as demilitarized zones or DMZs. Restricting or prohibiting interfaces within organizational systems includes restricting external web traffic to designated web servers within managed interfaces, prohibiting external traffic that appears to be spoofing internal addresses, and prohibiting internal traffic that appears to be spoofing external addresses. [SP 800-189] provides additional information on source address validation techniques to prevent ingress and egress of traffic with spoofed addresses. Commercial telecommunications services are provided by network components and consolidated management systems shared by customers. These services may also include third party-provided access lines and other service elements. Such services may represent sources of increased risk despite contract security provisions. Boundary protection may be implemented as a common control for all or part of an organizational network such that the boundary to be protected is greater than a system-specific boundary (i.e., an authorization boundary).

subsection_controls.Name: (5) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: DENY BY DEFAULT — ALLOW BY EXCEPTION
control.discussion: Denying by default and allowing by exception applies to inbound and outbound network communications traffic. A deny-all, permit-by-exception network communications traffic policy ensures that only those system connections that are essential and approved are allowed. Deny by default, allow by exception also applies to a system that is connected to an external system.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. Subnetworks that are physically or logically separated from internal networks are referred to as demilitarized zones or DMZs. subsection_controls.Name: (7) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: SPLIT TUNNELING FOR REMOTE DEVICES
control.discussion: Split tunneling is the process of allowing a remote user or device to establish a non-remote connection with a system and simultaneously communicate via some other connection to a resource in an external network. This method of network access enables a user to access remote devices and simultaneously, access uncontrolled networks. Split tunneling might be desirable by remote users to communicate with local system resources, such as printers or file servers. However, split tunneling can facilitate unauthorized external connections, making the system vulnerable to attack and to exfiltration of organizational information. Split tunneling can be prevented by disabling configuration settings that allow such capability in remote devices and by preventing those configuration settings from being configurable by users. Prevention can also be achieved by the detection of split tunneling (or of configuration settings that allow split tunneling) in the remote device, and by prohibiting the connection if the remote device is using split tunneling. A virtual private network (VPN) can be used to securely provision a split tunnel. A securely provisioned VPN includes locking connectivity to exclusive, managed, and named environments, or to a specific set of pre-approved addresses, without user control.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. Subnetworks that are physically or logically separated from internal networks are referred to as demilitarized zones or DMZs. Restricting or prohibiting interfaces within organizational systems includes restricting external web traffic to designated web servers within managed interfaces, prohibiting external traffic that appears to be spoofing internal addresses, and prohibiting internal traffic that appears to be spoofing external addresses. [SP 800-189] provides additional information on source address validation techniques to prevent ingress and egress of traffic with spoofed addresses. Commercial telecommunications services are provided by network components and consolidated management systems shared by customers. These services may also include third party-provided access lines and other service elements. Such services may represent sources of increased risk despite contract security provisions. Boundary protection may be implemented as a common control for all or part of an organizational network such that the boundary to be protected is greater than a system-specific boundary (i.e., an authorization boundary).

subsection_controls.Name: (8) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: ROUTE TRAFFIC TO AUTHENTICATED PROXY SERVERS
control.discussion: External networks are networks outside of organizational control. A proxy server is a server (i.e., system or application) that acts as an intermediary for clients requesting system resources from non-organizational or other organizational servers. System resources that may be requested include files, connections, web pages, or services. Client requests established through a connection to a proxy server are assessed to manage complexity and provide additional protection by limiting direct connectivity. Web content filtering devices are one of the most common proxy servers that provide access to the Internet. Proxy servers can support the logging of Transmission Control Protocol sessions and the blocking of specific Uniform Resource Locators, Internet Protocol addresses, and domain names. Web proxies can be configured with organization-defined lists of authorized and unauthorized websites. Note that proxy servers may inhibit the use of virtual private networks (VPNs) and create the potential for 'man-in-the-middle' attacks (depending on the implementation).

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. Subnetworks that are physically or logically separated from internal networks are referred to as demilitarized zones or DMZs. Restricting or prohibiting interfaces within organizational systems includes restricting external web traffic to designated web servers within managed interfaces, prohibiting external traffic that appears to be spoofing internal addresses, and prohibiting internal traffic that appears to be spoofing external addresses. [SP 800-189] provides additional information on source address validation techniques to prevent ingress and egress of traffic with spoofed addresses. Commercial telecommunications services are provided by network components and consolidated management systems shared by customers. These services may also include third party-provided access lines and other service elements. Such services may represent sources of increased risk despite contract security provisions. Boundary protection may be implemented as a common control for all or part of an organizational network such that the boundary to be protected is greater than a system-specific boundary (i.e., an authorization boundary).

subsection_controls.Name: (9) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: RESTRICT THREATENING OUTGOING COMMUNICATIONS TRAFFIC
control.discussion: Detecting outgoing communications traffic from internal actions that may pose threats to external systems is known as extrusion detection. Extrusion detection is carried out within the system at managed interfaces. Extrusion detection includes the analysis of incoming and outgoing communications traffic while searching for indications of internal threats to the security of external systems. Internal threats to external systems include traffic indicative of denial-of-service attacks, traffic with spoofed source addresses, and traffic that contains malicious code. Organizations have criteria to determine, update, and manage identified threats related to extrusion detection.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. Subnetworks that are physically or logically separated from internal networks are referred to as demilitarized zones or DMZs. Restricting or prohibiting interfaces within organizational systems includes restricting external web traffic to designated web servers within managed interfaces, prohibiting external traffic that appears to be spoofing internal addresses, and prohibiting internal traffic that appears to be spoofing external addresses. [SP 800-189] provides additional information on source address validation techniques to prevent ingress and egress of traffic with spoofed addresses. Commercial telecommunications services are provided by network components and consolidated management systems shared by customers. These services may also include third party-provided access lines and other service elements. Such services may represent sources of increased risk despite contract security provisions. Boundary protection may be implemented as a common control for all or part of an organizational network such that the boundary to be protected is greater than a system-specific boundary (i.e., an authorization boundary).

subsection_controls.Name: (10) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: PREVENT EXFILTRATION
control.discussion: Prevention of exfiltration applies to both the intentional and unintentional exfiltration of information. Techniques used to prevent the exfiltration of information from systems may be implemented at internal endpoints, external boundaries, and across managed interfaces and include adherence to protocol formats, monitoring for beaconing activity from systems, disconnecting external network interfaces except when explicitly needed, employing traffic profile analysis to detect deviations from the volume and types of traffic expected, call backs to command and control centers, conducting penetration testing, monitoring for steganography, disassembling and reassembling packet headers, and using data loss and data leakage prevention tools. Devices that enforce strict adherence to protocol formats include deep packet inspection firewalls and Extensible Markup Language (XML) gateways. The devices verify adherence to protocol formats and specifications at the application layer and identify vulnerabilities that cannot be detected by devices that operate at the network or transport layers. The prevention of exfiltration is similar to data loss prevention or data leakage prevention and is closely associated with cross-domain solutions and system guards that enforce information flow requirements.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. Subnetworks that are physically or logically separated from internal networks are referred to as demilitarized zones or DMZs. Restricting or prohibiting interfaces within organizational systems includes restricting external web traffic to designated web servers within managed interfaces, prohibiting external traffic that appears to be spoofing internal addresses, and prohibiting internal traffic that appears to be spoofing external addresses. [SP 800-189] provides additional information on source address validation techniques to prevent ingress and egress of traffic with spoofed addresses. Commercial telecommunications services are provided by network components and consolidated management systems shared by customers. These services may also include third party-provided access lines and other service elements. Such services may represent sources of increased risk despite contract security provisions. Boundary protection may be implemented as a common control for all or part of an organizational network such that the boundary to be protected is greater than a system-specific boundary (i.e., an authorization boundary).

subsection_controls.Name: (11) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: RESTRICT INCOMING COMMUNICATIONS TRAFFIC
control.discussion: General source address validation techniques are applied to restrict the use of illegal and unallocated source addresses as well as source addresses that should only be used within the system. The restriction of incoming communications traffic provides determinations that source and destination address pairs represent authorized or allowed communications. Determinations can be based on several factors, including the presence of such address pairs in the lists of authorized or allowed communications, the absence of such address pairs in lists of unauthorized or disallowed pairs, or meeting more general rules for authorized or allowed source and destination pairs. Strong authentication of network addresses is not possible without the use of explicit security protocols, and thus, addresses can often be spoofed. Further, identity-based incoming traffic restriction methods can be employed, including router access control lists and firewall rules.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. Subnetworks that are physically or logically separated from internal networks are referred to as demilitarized zones or DMZs. Restricting or prohibiting interfaces within organizational systems includes restricting external web traffic to designated web servers within managed interfaces, prohibiting external traffic that appears to be spoofing internal addresses, and prohibiting internal traffic that appears to be spoofing external addresses. [SP 800-189] provides additional information on source address validation techniques to prevent ingress and egress of traffic with spoofed addresses. Commercial telecommunications services are provided by network components and consolidated management systems shared by customers. These services may also include third party-provided access lines and other service elements. Such services may represent sources of increased risk despite contract security provisions. Boundary protection may be implemented as a common control for all or part of an organizational network such that the boundary to be protected is greater than a system-specific boundary (i.e., an authorization boundary).

subsection_controls.Name: (12) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: HOST-BASED PROTECTION
control.discussion: Host-based boundary protection mechanisms include host-based firewalls. System components that employ host-based boundary protection mechanisms include servers, workstations, notebook computers, and mobile devices.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. subsection_controls.Name: (13) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: ISOLATION OF SECURITY TOOLS, MECHANISMS, AND SUPPORT COMPONENTS
control.discussion: Physically separate subnetworks with managed interfaces are useful in isolating computer network defenses from critical operational processing networks to prevent adversaries from discovering the analysis and forensics techniques employed by organizations.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. subsection_controls.Name: (14) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: PROTECT AGAINST UNAUTHORIZED PHYSICAL CONNECTIONS
control.discussion: Systems that operate at different security categories or classification levels may share common physical and environmental controls, since the systems may share space within the same facilities. In practice, it is possible that these separate systems may share common equipment rooms, wiring closets, and cable distribution paths. Protection against unauthorized physical connections can be achieved by using clearly identified and physically separated cable trays, connection frames, and patch panels for each side of managed interfaces with physical access controls that enforce limited authorized access to these items.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. Subnetworks that are physically or logically separated from internal networks are referred to as demilitarized zones or DMZs. subsection_controls.Name: (15) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: NETWORKED PRIVILEGED ACCESSES
control.discussion: Privileged access provides greater accessibility to system functions, including security functions. Adversaries attempt to gain privileged access to systems through remote access to cause adverse mission or business impacts, such as by exfiltrating information or bringing down a critical system capability. Routing networked, privileged access requests through a dedicated, managed interface further restricts privileged access for increased access control and auditing.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. Subnetworks that are physically or logically separated from internal networks are referred to as demilitarized zones or DMZs. subsection_controls.Name: (16) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: PREVENT DISCOVERY OF SYSTEM COMPONENTS
control.discussion: Preventing the discovery of system components representing a managed interface helps protect network addresses of those components from discovery through common tools and techniques used to identify devices on networks. Network addresses are not available for discovery and require prior knowledge for access. Preventing the discovery of components and devices can be accomplished by not publishing network addresses, using network address translation, or not entering the addresses in domain name systems. Another prevention technique is to periodically change network addresses.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. subsection_controls.Name: (17) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: AUTOMATED ENFORCEMENT OF PROTOCOL FORMATS
control.discussion: System components that enforce protocol formats include deep packet inspection firewalls and XML gateways. The components verify adherence to protocol formats and specifications at the application layer and identify vulnerabilities that cannot be detected by devices operating at the network or transport layers.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. subsection_controls.Name: (18) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: FAIL SECURE
control.discussion: Fail secure is a condition achieved by employing mechanisms to ensure that in the event of operational failures of boundary protection devices at managed interfaces, systems do not enter into unsecure states where intended security properties no longer hold. Managed interfaces include routers, firewalls, and application gateways that reside on protected subnetworks (commonly referred to as demilitarized zones). Failures of boundary protection devices cannot lead to or cause information external to the devices to enter the devices nor can failures permit unauthorized information releases.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. Subnetworks that are physically or logically separated from internal networks are referred to as demilitarized zones or DMZs. subsection_controls.Name: (19) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: BLOCK COMMUNICATION FROM NON-ORGANIZATIONALLY CONFIGURED HOSTS
control.discussion: Communication clients independently configured by end users and external service providers include instant messaging clients and video conferencing software and applications. Traffic blocking does not apply to communication clients that are configured by organizations to perform authorized functions.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. subsection_controls.Name: (20) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: DYNAMIC ISOLATION AND SEGREGATION
control.discussion: The capability to dynamically isolate certain internal system components is useful when it is necessary to partition or separate system components of questionable origin from components that possess greater trustworthiness. Component isolation reduces the attack surface of organizational systems. Isolating selected system components can also limit the damage from successful attacks when such attacks occur.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. Subnetworks that are physically or logically separated from internal networks are referred to as demilitarized zones or DMZs. Restricting or prohibiting interfaces within organizational systems includes restricting external web traffic to designated web servers within managed interfaces, prohibiting external traffic that appears to be spoofing internal addresses, and prohibiting internal traffic that appears to be spoofing external addresses. [SP 800-189] provides additional information on source address validation techniques to prevent ingress and egress of traffic with spoofed addresses. Commercial telecommunications services are provided by network components and consolidated management systems shared by customers. Boundary protection may be implemented as a common control for all or part of an organizational network such that the boundary to be protected is greater than a system-specific boundary (i.e., an authorization boundary).

subsection_controls.Name: (21) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: ISOLATION OF SYSTEM COMPONENTS
control.discussion: Organizations can isolate system components that perform different mission or business functions. Such isolation limits unauthorized information flows among system components and provides the opportunity to deploy greater levels of protection for selected system components. Isolating system components with boundary protection mechanisms provides the capability for increased protection of individual system components and to more effectively control information flows between those components. Isolating system components provides enhanced protection that limits the potential harm from hostile cyber attacks and errors. The degree of isolation varies depending upon the mechanisms chosen. Boundary protection mechanisms include routers, gateways, and firewalls that separate system components into physically separate networks or subnetworks; cross-domain devices that separate subnetworks; virtualization techniques; and the encryption of information flows among system components using distinct encryption keys.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. Subnetworks that are physically or logically separated from internal networks are referred to as demilitarized zones or DMZs. subsection_controls.Name: (22) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: SEPARATE SUBNETS FOR CONNECTING TO DIFFERENT SECURITY DOMAINS
control.discussion: The decomposition of systems into subnetworks (i.e., subnets) helps to provide the appropriate level of protection for network connections to different security domains that contain information with different security categories or classification levels.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. control.title: DISABLE SENDER FEEDBACK ON PROTOCOL VALIDATION FAILURE
control.discussion: Disabling feedback to senders when there is a failure in protocol validation format prevents adversaries from obtaining information that would otherwise be unavailable.

subsection_controls.Name: (24) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: PERSONALLY IDENTIFIABLE INFORMATION
control.discussion: Managing the processing of personally identifiable information is an important aspect of protecting an individual's privacy. Applying, monitoring for, and documenting exceptions to processing rules ensure that personally identifiable information is processed only in accordance with established privacy requirements.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. subsection_controls.Name: (25) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: UNCLASSIFIED NATIONAL SECURITY SYSTEM CONNECTIONS
control.discussion: A direct connection is a dedicated physical or virtual connection between two or more systems. Organizations typically do not have complete control over external networks, including the Internet. Boundary protection devices (e.g., firewalls, gateways, and routers) mediate communications and information flows between unclassified national security systems and external networks.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. Subnetworks that are physically or logically separated from internal networks are referred to as demilitarized zones or DMZs. Commercial telecommunications services are provided by network components and consolidated management systems shared by customers. subsection_controls.Name: (26) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: CLASSIFIED NATIONAL SECURITY SYSTEM CONNECTIONS
control.discussion: A direct connection is a dedicated physical or virtual connection between two or more systems. Organizations typically do not have complete control over external networks, including the Internet. Boundary protection devices (e.g., firewalls, gateways, and routers) mediate communications and information flows between classified national security systems and external networks. In addition, approved boundary protection devices (typically managed interface or cross-domain systems) provide information flow enforcement from systems to external networks.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture. subsection_controls.Name: (28) - BOUNDARY PROTECTION

control.title: CONNECTIONS TO PUBLIC NETWORKS
control.discussion: A direct connection is a dedicated physical or virtual connection between two or more systems. A public network is a network accessible to the public, including the Internet and organizational extranets with public access.

subsection_controls.discussion: Managed interfaces include gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, network-based malicious code analysis, virtualization systems, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture.
